comments.commentBody: It's not the expensive material objects, it's the little things that we hold dearest about our lost loved ones. I have a to do list of my mother's I enjoy looking at occasionally just for her handwriting alone. And what mother doesn't have a to do list? Pieces of paper and what we wrote on them are often small snapshots of our daily lives.

Thank you for this beautiful essay, Ms. Wilson.
My mother died over thirty years ago. The amount of time my six siblings and I had with her varied, of course, according to our ages, and we have separate memories of her, along with our shared recollections.
To this day, though, we are identical in how very much we still miss her.

Thank you Mara I am a father of two young boys almost seven and three who lost their mum to cancer a year ago, a lot of what you write about your mother resonates. Thank you for sharing this experience, it gave me comfort about what will remain, the essential, love.
I thought that too -- until I decided that maybe an even more important lesson is, "Don't wait."
Thank you very much.

My story is similar because I am not religious either but my Mom had solar bulbs which would come in after dark on her balcony. I brought them home with me so that when those lights go on at night it is like she is saying hello.

My mom died suddenly in June 1994. I say suddenly because she experienced cardiac arrest while undergoing electroshock therapy for the mental issues that plagued the last three years of her life. She passed away three days later.

I was the model of composure until it was just my father, my brother and myself at the funeral home after the service. Then the floodgates opened...heaving, wracking sobs I'd held in for a week.

My partner and I moved to Florida last year and one of the first things we noticed were the number of cardinals hanging around the condo complex. My mom loved cardinals and whenever I see them, which is still almost on a daily basis, I feel like a piece of her is here. I don't believe in God and am not the least bit spiritual, but whatever the reasons, I look out of the back window some days and say a quiet "Hi Mom" to them.
It was entered in her calendar.......
The NY Times loves your comments and publishes them often. Why not be kind to others and their opinions?

Uh...so how come "traditional" religions go to such great lengths to...well...actually denigrate women? Its the very differences between the sexes, most of them based on these ridiculous myths, that still permeate these "traditional"(I prefer ancient, or outdated) religions and their practices. Why cant women and men pray together in Judaism or Islam?

Oh...right...the men, they cant think or worship properly with the distraction of females. And of course their God, well...he cant tolerate it either. Its always the females fault men cant think with anything above the waist. And well...there's that female impurity too...all that yucky female stuff...so not suited for spiritual or intellectual pursuits.

There are but a few actual differences (all purely physical, and often even those - outside of reproduction, are not for certain depending on the individuals being compared) between the male and female. But NONE of them have a thing to do with their higher spiritual beliefs, where, and/or how they should pursue them. Religions are by nature, especially those followed "traditionally" sexist! No escaping it.
Only stay at home mothers are full-time mothers?  I am every bit a full time mother thank you very much, even though I also have a career.  Kids are in school all day, by the way.

Long Island, I can hear the hurt and frustration in your words, but your comments are not appropriate for this thread.  The article is about the love of a parent and the feelings of loss and grief at her early passing, and how her children remember her.  Not religious or cultural practices.  I appreciate those sharing similar stories.

In the Jewish tradition, men are required to spend many, many hours a week uttering prayers. No such requirement is imposed on Mothers.

This is because a woman, who gives her life to her children, gets closer to God that any man, no matter how many prayers he recites.

Many people repudiate traditional Judaism -- and traditional Christianity and Islam and other traditions in general -- because it is allegedly sexist.

However, these traditional outlooks are not meant to denigrate women. We perceive differences between the genders, but acknowledging differences between men and women is not the same things as demoting women to a lower status.

Quite frankly, who is doing a more useful thing: A man who composes advertisements for cigarettes, or a woman who lovingly raises her children.

Women who are full time Moms should never be ashamed of their status, and the world around them should celebrate their heroic, selfless stance in life.
Thank you Alan.  She definitely was.  Have a wonderful weekend.
yeah, except so many of them don't.

Unless a woman's dream is to be a mother and raise children, that is indeed a fact.

That so many young people considering parenthood are unaware of this is, no doubt, one of the reasons so many relationships fail after a child is born.

They seem totally unprepared for the amount of time, money, and sacrifices in raising children, as if they thought their lives would stay exactly the same, except for that cute Hallmark Channel baby who would sleep on command.

There is only so much time in a day and no one can have it all, not at the same time. Better that prospective parents know this beforehand and choose wisely.
You will see that your "irritation" is because you fear losing her.
A lovely essay, it brought a tear to my eye.

My mother was 52 when my bipolar engineer father choked her to death at a 8 a.m. on February 10, 1967, in New Brunswick NJ.  She was a natural beauty and a Southern charmer.  Dyslexic, she had never attended college because her high school grades were so bad.  She envied educated people, and in autumn 1966 enrolled in a class at Rutgers.  The Monday after her death, in the mail was an envelope from Rutgers, addressed to her.  Inside was her grade for the class:  an A.  She made an A, her first ever A.  And didn't live to see the payoff for her hard work.  I still have her grade, along with her autopsy.
Beautiful and touching. A wonderful tribute to your mother. I'm sure she was terrific.

Well, this will be an interesting read and reminds me to be grateful my parents raised me within no organized religion. This is supposed to be a religious place yet people push and shove each other, pee all over the place, and sexually assault women who bend over to tie their shoe laces? Now, I've been to churches, synagogues, and temples and have not been submitted to those types of behaviors. It's amazing how religion can be used to justify everything.

I am surprised and saddened to hear that sexual assault is a serious risk during the Hajj. I never feared sexual assault (harassment in outside streets absolutely, although it was infrequent and less threatening than what I have grown accustomed to in the US) when I visited the Vatican and the great cathedrals of Spain alone two years ago. I hope the Saudi authorities crack down, it is awful women must go through that during one of the most important spiritual experiences of their lives.

I hope you have a wonderful pilgrimage! I am not religious and have not been since my childhood, but still found my trip filled a gap I had long ignored. I hope also that you and other women continue to be frank and open about the issues women face on the Hajj, because only with sunlight will things change. Thank you.
Why not? For centuries, religion has been used as justification for theft, war, murder, etc. much less sexual assault.

The processing capability of Mecca tops out at about 3 million a year, and that is not without fatalities. Over 100 years that's 300 million people, out of 1.5 billion Moslems. So the chances of becoming a Hajji are reasonable, if you're a betting man, but the odds are against. Over a 70 year life span "only" 210 million people will cycle through, so your chance of making it at all is 14%, and less if you exclude early childhood and extreme old age. It also raises an equity issue if people make the trip more than once.

If we look at the pilgrimage as a sheer numbers and space problem, with attendant difficulties like providing food, water, and bathroom facilities, you would do what Disneyland does, which is build more facilities. Limited to one site, you might be able to increase the throughput by streamlining the rituals. But it is clear that the maximum capacity of the "physical plant," so to speak, has been reached.
To add to my recent post: I have visited many mosques in Malaysia too. No trouble for this Christian woman.

I completely welcome her honesty, to herself and to her readers.
She very likely DOES understand the importance of this place and the reason for it. However she has doubts about the reality of the beliefs that bestow that importance.

The "light inside" you refer to is the kind of blind faith that is the sign of a mind too weak or afraid to face the uncertainties and unknowns of human existence.

That's a bit harsh.

People's views are shaped at different stages of their spiritual journey. Some may feel a difference the moment they embark on Hajj, many others feel it at end of their pilgrimage. I've known several people who didn't feel much in Makkah - partly because of the tough environment and heightened expectations - but underwent a transformation within the peace and serenity of Medina. Still many come and go feeling the same, but only reflect upon their experience years later. A lot of it has to do with who a person accompanies - generally the more focused the group on pilgrimage itself, the more lasting the effects.

As for this reporter, I can understand why she feels they way she describes. Journalists, by virtue of their profession, are skeptics and critical. Having been raised a muslim exposed to liberal secular values, it can become difficult to reconcile the conflicting sets of values.

It was all good until the last sentence (in the video): "I really struggle with the idea that some places are holier than others." This -completely- defeats the purpose of the pilgrimage itself for this individual, and sadly it underscores her gross lack of knowledge of the Islamic faith itself. The reporter is right there, in the heart of the greatest spiritual place, where prophet Abraham built the first place of monotheistic worship, where the last prophet, Muhammad, was born, and yet, she completely misses out on the meaning of surrending to the absolute love from God in this very spot on earth where believers are asked to travel. If she does not have that light inside, well she'd better off at home indeed.

It's interesting to read people say that they are happy to finally read about what Islam is really about, not the so-called perverted version of extremists and their blood-soaked antics.

But what is the "true nature" of Islam--or any religion? There are as many versions of any religion as there are believers. And peaceful or violent, who is to say what is the truth?

In my view believing--any belief, and this nation's idolatry of religion's without taxation--involves adhering to no code, ethic, or understanding but your own.

As an American I believe in a god, in what Donald Trump says, that vaccines cause autism, that Obama is a Muslim, that human-induced climate change is a hoax.

Some may fail to see the connection between religion and these views, but in a nation that is saturated with "belief," it's difficult not to see it.

And don't forget to make sure the life insurance policy is paid up - seems to be part of the tradition that there is a stampede of various dimensions that results in the death of hundreds each time. What a way to honor your lord.

Julie S. - It may be possible for non Catholics to receive communion in a Catholic church, but it is forbidden. Generally communion is given to anyone who presents himself, so I'm sure the occasional non Catholic does in fact receive. Unlike some other Christian churches, Catholics do not practice open communion.

However, attendance at the Catholic mass, unlike communion, is indeed open to all. People of any religion or no religion are all welcome.
